title: Telling and selling Literary fiction in early Malay language newspapers in colonial Indonesia - Joachim Nieβ
summary:
When newspapers in the colloquial Malay language appeared in the Dutch East Indies in the middle of the nineteenth century, they did more than just publish news reports and advertisements. They also created a new platform for the telling and distribution of literary fiction. In effect, literary texts soon played an important role in the vernacular print media. The first part of this article analyses the attraction of newspaper literature from the perspective of both the reader and the editor in general and gives a survey of the various forms of literary genres which can be found in newspapers in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century. In the second part, one particular serialized novel will be discussed in detail to demonstrate how the mode of publication also influenced the way stories were told.

title: The creation of monolanguaging space in a krámá Javanese language performance
summary: Recent approaches to multilingualism, such as translanguaging, emphasize the porous, fluid, and hybrid nature of language use. This article intends to show, through an example of a local language debating competition in Central Java, that culturally emblematic performances tend to create monolanguaging spaces, due to their monolingual focusing on certain language varieties that are iconic to local ethnolinguistic identity. Monolanguaging spaces are language ideological spaces in which speakers project an idealized performance of their ethnolinguistic identity. Ethnographic observation shows that the performance of monolanguaging spaces involves the erasure of speakers' multilingual repertoires and translanguaging practices, in accordance to the language ideology surrounding the hegemonic prestigious language variety and in accordance to the local norms of status or power-based social interaction. Attending to monolanguaging spaces reveal it as a performance accomplished through discursive work and power relations, involving the misrecognition of its connection and dissonance to multilingual repertoires and practices.

title: Jinising Lelembut Misuwur Ing Rusia
summary: Crita ing ngisor iki minangka pakurmatan tumrap baline sedulur tuwa, yaiku Rusia kang nate menehi bantuwan, rikalane Indonesia ngadhepi tilas penjajah Landa ngrebut Papua, bali menyang pangkone Ibu Pertiwi. Maneka warna bantuwan kang diwenehake marang Indonesia, saengga wektu kuwi Indonesia misuwur minangka salah sawijine negara kanthi kekuwatan militer kang paling ngedab-edabi ing Asia. Sadurunge agama Kristen mlebu ing Rusia, warga Rusia nyembah sawenehi dewa lan roh-roh alus. Saliyane iku uga isih sesambungan marang sawenehing lelembut. Kapitayan kasebut ngrembaka lan uga isih dilestarekake nganti saiki. Sawenehe lelembut sing kaloka kaya kasebut ing ngisor iki. Vodyanoy Vodyanoy minangka sesebutan marang lelembut sing tunggu kali, sendhang utawa laut. Lelembut iki kaloka karana laut lan kali ing jaman biyen misuwur minangka dalane dedagangan para mina lan sudagar-sudagar ing Rusia utamane Rusia Lor, cedhak karo laut Putih. Wujude Vodyanoy dhewe kaya dene manungsa dhuyung, dheweke kadi dene rajane laut kang kudu sinembah lan sinubya-subya. Vodyanoy duwe anak lanang lan wadon kang kaloka kaya ta putri lan putra dhuyung, kanthi warna kulite biru utawa ireng. Vodyanoyasring muncul ing wayah bengi, njungkati rambute sing warnane putih semu perak, kaya dene suket laut ing sapinggire kali. Vodyanoy gawe angger-angger ing wilayahe, sing baku sakabehe tumindake manungsa kang ana gegayutane karo kali, kayata mancing, adus, njupuk banyu, nyabarangi kali, lan liya-liyane ora kena ditindakake ing wayah wengi. title: In the Centre of an Empire. Archaeological and Historical Memorial places in Indonesia (English resume)
summary:
In the Centre of an Empire. Archaeological and Histori-cal Memorial places in Indonesia
One  of  the  most  important  archaeological  parks  of  Indonesia,  called 
Trowulan, is located in East Jawa. Between the 13th–16th centuries, it 
was the centre of the great Majapahit Empire and nowadays it is the part 
of Mojokerto kabupaten, approximately 50 km far southwest of Sura-baya. The site covers roughly 100 square kilometres, however, its exact 
borders are still unknown.
It lies on a fertile plain at slopes of several volcanoes, such as the Gunung 
Kojor (2352 m) or the Gunung Argowayang (2198 m). As the archaeo-logical records show, thanks to the favourable natural conditions the rich 
lands helped to build a lourishing economy. Furthermore, key position 
of Trowulan provided access to Madura, Bali, Central Java, the Java sea 
and the Indian ocean and also formed complex interregional trading con-nections with Chinese kingdoms or the Indian subcontinent.
At the same time, despite the great signiicance of the site, Trowulan can 
still be considered as a less acknowledged ield in European archaeolo-gy. Therefore, the paper aims to give a general overview on history of the 
Majapahit Empire and also intends to describe the most noted remains 
discovered in ancient city of Trowulan, richly illustrated by unpublished 
photos taken by the author.

title: Pemrograman Objek Dasar Modul 1
Hofstra Symposium November 3, 2016- Traditions in Transition: Intangible Cultural Heritage in South and Southeast Asia
summary: Hofstra University will be presenting a symposium on November 3, 2016 that unites scholars from the disciplines of anthropology, ethnomusicology, folklore, theater and Asian studies to sacred traditions of South and Southeast Asia. Through the participation in workshops given by scholar-practitioners, performances of a central Javanese Gamelan orchestra, Sundanese rod puppetry theater, Sikh religious hymns, academic lectures, and a one-day installation of an exhibit of Malay puppets, costumes, instruments, and ethnographic photos of healing performances, participants in this symposium will gain insight into complex performance forms and explore the paradoxical issues currently facing the traditional arts and their definition as intangible cultural heritage in South and Southeast Asia.

title: Jawajski teatr cieni wayang kulit, [w:] Bogowie i ludzie. Współczesna religijność w Azji Południowo-Wschodniej, red. Sylwia Gil, Adrian Mianecki, Toruń 2016, s. 215-248.
Ecological factors in the transfer of the seat of government from Central Java to East Java in the tenth century
“Home grown music is tasty”: liminality and locality in a musical community in the city of Solo, Central Java, Indonesia
summary: On the edge of Solo, a city famous for its rich cultural heritage, a graffiti-covered boarding house was home to a musical community making music including reggae, metal and traditionally-inspired percussion fusion. Drawing on ethnographic fieldwork and theoretical perspectives on musical communities (Finnegan 1989, Cohen 1991), this paper explores the distinctive ways in which these musicians negotiated their unique social and musical positions. Socially, I situate the community as at once liminal and unconventional yet firmly rooted in its place and local identity, drawing selectively on elements of the monolithic ‘Javanese culture’. Musically, I show how the community blurred boundaries between genres assumed to have distinct ‘scenes’, and between popular and traditional musics, forming a point of connection between state-endorsed versions of Indonesian culture and global youth subcultures. Together, these factors enabled the community to create its unique scene, connected to a variety of local and international musical ‘worlds’.

title: Text, temple, and tirtha
Mandalas, Grids, and Volcanic Eruptions: Notes on the Persistence of Old Geographies in Modern Central Java
summary: The death of Mbah Maridjan, "Keeper of the Keys" of Merapi Volcano during an eruption of the mountain, occasioned a reflection on his last interview given to westerners, in this case University of Michigan students. The two very different worlds they co-inhabited simultaneously points to the dissonances between increasingly disappearing older knowledge of the world in a "modern" scientific age.

title: Majority and Minority: Preserving Animist and Mystical Practices in Far East Java
summary: Most people in rural Banyuwangi conform to a traditional style of Islam the call "Islam NU". Several villages, by contrast, actively maintain animist and mystical practices.

title: Wird Indonesiens Erbe der Menschheit verkauft? Die Auswirkungen der Implementierung des TRIPS-Abkommens auf die traditionelle Jamu-Heilkräuterkunde in Indonesien und der Gestaltungsraum für mögliche Schutzmechanismen
Alun-alun, the space of complicity
TAMAN ING KUTHO SUROBOYO
"Abot lan Nyenen-Kemis: Pasinaon Basa Jawa ing Mancanagara" [In Javanese: "Difficult and struggling to survive: The study of Javanese outside Indonesia"] Suara Merdeka 27 Februari 2012
Candi, Space and Landscape. A study on the distribution, orientation and spatial organization of Central Javanese temple remains
summary:
Central Javanese temples were not built anywhere and anyhow. On the contrary: their positions within the landscape and their architectural designs were determined by socio-cultural, religious and economic factors. This book explores the correlations between temple distribution, natural surroundings and architectural design to understand how Central Javanese people structured the space around them, and how the religious landscape thus created developed.

Besides questions related to territory and landscape, this book analyzes the structure of the built space and its possible relations with conceptualized space, showing the influence of imported Indian concepts, as well as their limits.

Going off the beaten track, the present study explores the hundreds of small sites that scatter the landscape of Central Java. It is also one of very few studies to apply the methods of spatial archaeology to Central Javanese temples and the first in almost one century to present a descriptive inventory of the remains of this region.
